awd_titl_txt: FRG: Collaborative Research: Algebra and Geometry Behind Link Homology
awd_abstract_narration:
The Hecke algebra and its generalizations are central objects in modern representation theory. They naturally appear in number theory, representation theory, algebraic geometry, and even low-dimensional topology. A categorification of the Hecke algebra was used to define a new topological invariant of knots and links, known as HOMFLY-PT homology. However, it is extremely difficult to compute this invariant from the definition. The project is focused on understanding the algebraic, geometric, and combinatorial structure of link homology and categorified Hecke algebras, with the goal of unifying, deepening, and clarifying connections between these concepts.

Recent progress strongly indicates a connection between the HOMFLY-PT homology and algebraic geometry of the Hilbert scheme of points on the plane, a central object in modern algebraic geometry and geometric representation theory.  In this collaborative project, the investigators plan to compare and unify different approaches to the study of this connection and to develop the fundamental understanding of the relation between the category of Soergel bimodules and the Hilbert scheme. They also plan to provide an algebro-geometric construction of HOMFLY-PT homology and to understand its relation to the combinatorics of Macdonald polynomials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
When braiding a long head of hair, one has several cables of hair running up and down, woven betwixt each other. The mathematical concept of a braid is quite similar, a number of strands fixed attached at the top and bottom, but tangled with each other in between. Connecting the top and bottom, one obtains a tangled mass of circular strands, called a knot; in this case, the knot is the closure of a braid. It is very hard to tell whether two knots are secretly the same (one can get from one to the other by wiggling the strands of hair, without using scissors), so mathematicians rely on algebraic invariants of knots known as knot invariants. Knot invariants have connections to many fields in mathematics, from representation theory to topology to geometry. One of the more exciting aspects of knot invariants is how they build bridges between fields, and illuminate unexpected coincidences and equivalences between constructions from very different contexts.

One knot invariant of central importance, originally studied in the early 2000s, is called HOMFLYPT homology. The major mathematical goal of this collaborative FRG grant was to bring together experts on HOMFLYPT homology from different angles: topological, algebraic, geometric, and combinatorial.  In particular, a focal point is a recent conjecture of Gorsky (one of the PIs), Negut, and Rasmussen (GNR), which states an equivalence between part of the Hecke category (an algebraic object) and some kind of data attached to the Hilbert scheme (a geometric object).  HOMFLYPT homology was originally defined using the Hecke category, but people had observed that it seemed to agree with computations made using the Hilbert scheme. The GNR conjecture would explain this phenomenon, linking the two computations.

In particular, GNR did a lot of work on the geometric side, and proved what one might call the GNR Theorem. This states that the desired equivalence (the GNR conjecture) is true if one could only construct a very complicated object V on the algebraic side, and prove that it possesses certain properties (e.g. centrality, a kind of symmetry which is not easy to demonstrate).

I am an expert on the algebraic side of the story, the Hecke category. I suspected that there should be an "affine" analogue of the GNR conjecture, which instead studies braids wrapped around a maypole, or knots embedded in the surface of a donut. The first major accomplishment of this grant is a construction of the affine analogue of the object V. This construction took ideas developed earlier by Gaitsgory, and made them very explicit in the context of the Hecke category. A second major accomplishment was the thesis of Arjuna Hathaway, a PhD student of the PI, who formulated the affine GNR conjecture and affine GNR theorem, and showed that V has some of the properties required. The third and fourth accomplishments have not yet been written down, and are joint work in progress between the PI and Matthew Hogancamp. The third includes a construction of V in the original setting of GNR, as well as other techniques to produce objects in Hecke categories with nice centrality properties. The fourth provides "homological" techniques needed to study centrality properties, and to study a conjectural "flattening" map which relates the affine and original settings.

There was a large overlap between this grant and COVID-19, so one of the goals of the grant, which was to bring the co-PIs physically together to make progress, did not occur as planned.

However, we did have opportunities to bring together the community of researchers in the form of several conferences, some in person and some online. This particular subgrant of the FRG grant supported two conferences, one online in the summer of 2020, and one in person at the University of Oregon in the summer of 2022 (thanks to a no-cost extension). Named QUACKS and QUACKS II, these conferences brought together experts in knot theory and categorification, and supported many graduate students and postdoctoral fellows to attend. The online conference QUACKS had 225 registrants, while the in-person conference QUACKS II had about 65 attendees. All talks at the online conference QUACKS can be found at the conference youtube channel.

In addition, both conferences featured a mini-workshop: three focused lectures by an expert intended for graduate students, and supported by exercise sessions. The intention was to enrich the experience for graduate students, and introduce a field which is otherwise not easy to learn. The lectures and exercises are still available on the conference webpage. The QUACKS minicourse was led by Qi You, and the QUACKS II minicourse was led by Daniel Tubbenhauer.

Another way in which this grant led to training and development is that it supported one graduate student to perform research during each of three summers.
